Zelenskyy: Mariupol is the heart of the war, it will stop beating - we will have weak positions

President Volodymyr Zelenskyy believes that the battles for eastern Ukraine and, in particular, for Mariupol, will determine the course of the war - and if the Armed Forces of Ukraine suffer a defeat there, the Russians may leave the negotiations and again occupy the de-occupied territories.
Direct speech: "Mariupol is, you know, the heart of this war today.
It is beating ‚Äì we are fighting, we are strong.
If it stops beating, we will have weaker positions.
They (defenders of the city ‚Äì ed.) are people who have attracted a large number of the enemy.

The stronger our position is in Mariupol, the stronger our position will be in the east of the state, in the (region) of the OOS, and if they are stronger, then the negotiating table will be closer to us and we will have advantages in the dialogue with the Russian Federation.
If we have a weak situation in all these directions, then we may not wait for a meeting.
Because then Russia will make all these steps that can lead to the return even to those cities that we are now de-occupied.
They can go and do it.
Then our situation in the negotiations will be weaker and, perhaps, even not interesting for the Russian side.
Unfortunately, we have to report.
We believe in our result, in our victory‚Ä¶".
Details: Zelensky also said that it is difficult to go to negotiations after the torture of Ukrainians, but "we must not lose the opportunity for a diplomatic solution if they are available to us.
Direct speech: "People will accept the world in any case, because people want this war to end.
Under our conditions, under the conditions of the independence of Ukraine, but ... every family has lost something - and I do not think that they will be satisfied with any peace on any conditions.
But if we talk not emotionally, the war must end with peace, or it will end with millions of victims.
And even there, where a million victims, everything comes to the end of the war.
Yes, we have to fight ‚Äì but for life.
You can't fight for the dust when there's nothing left, there's no one left.

After the Revolution of Dignity, the flight of Viktor Yanukovych, the annexation of Crimea and the beginning of the war in Donbas, the number of opponents of NATO began to fall, and the number of supporters, on the contrary, began to grow.<eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos>
After the start of the full-scale war with Russia, Ukrainian sociologists recorded a record level of support for Ukraine's accession to NATO among the citizens of Ukraine - more than 75%.

Despite the support for Ukraine's accession to NATO and the assistance that NATO is providing in the context of the war, there is now a lot of criticism of the Alliance and its member states - for the late supply of weapons, the refusal to close the sky, the unwillingness to "irritate" Russia.

In addition, there is a great risk that Ukraine will be forced to give up its desire to join the Alliance due to the position of the Russian Federation, if this can stop the war, and Ukraine will receive reliable security guarantees, including military ones.

In the new episode of the "Bloody Questions" podcast, together with the editor of "European Truth", we talk about how exactly the Alliance has helped Ukraine since the Russian invasion, what NATO should be criticized for, and what the Alliance is criticized for in vain, why our prospect of membership in NATO is closer than ever in history, and why security guarantees that are being discussed in negotiations with Russia can become the second Budapest Memorandum.

On March 1, the Russians hit the TV tower in Dorohozhychi near Babyn Yar, killing 5 passers-by as a result.
On March 2, Ukrainian air defense systems shot down Russian missiles over the South Railway Station, which were flying in the direction of the Ministry of Defense building.

The international community continues to express shock and outrage after evidence emerged that Russian forces committed atrocities against the civilian population in Ukraine, and Moscow rejected these reports as "provocation".
The message about the killed, raped and seriously injured civilians by the Russian army is worth condemning," said New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern to journalists in Wellington on April 4.
Russia must answer to the world for what they have done," she added, noting that her government will discuss additional measures to support Ukraine in its fight against the Russian invasion.
The Prime Minister of Japan Fumio Kishida called the incidents "a violation of international law".

Statements were made after the appearance of reports that hundreds of civilians were shot and thrown into mass graves or left on the streets in the suburbs of Kyiv, in Bucha, by Russian troops who left this area after occupying it for several weeks.
Photos showing the bodies of civilians with their hands tied shocked many and led to calls for tougher sanctions against Russia and criminal prosecution of the guilty.
French President Emmanuel Macron said in a radio interview on April 4 that there were signs that Russian troops had committed "war crimes" in Bucha.
What happened in Bucha requires a new round of sanctions and very clear measures," Macron said, adding that additional sanctions should be aimed at Russian coal and oil exports.
Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez said that Russian troops could go so far as to commit a "genocide" in Bucha.
We will do everything to ensure that those who committed these war crimes are not left unpunished," Sanchez said in Madrid.
Speaking on state television late on April 3, the spokeswoman for the Russian Foreign Ministry, Maria Zakharova, rejected the accusations as a "provocation.
She claimed without evidence that the United States and NATO "ordered" the images to discredit Russia.

In this case, it seems to me that the fact that these statements were made in the first minutes after the appearance of these materials does not cause any doubt as to who "ordered" this story," Zakharova said.
Earlier, the Russian Ministry of Defense also claimed without evidence that the images of Bucha were "another staging of the Kyiv regime" and that all Russian troops had left the city by March 30.
Moscow has asked the UN Security Council to meet on April 4 to discuss what it has called a "provocation by Ukrainian radicals" in Bucha.

The Russian Investigative Committee published a statement on April 4 announcing an investigation into Ukraine's dissemination of "knowingly false information" about the actions of Russian troops in Bucha.

President of Ukraine Volodymyr Zelenskyy spoke on April 3, accusing Russian troops of committing "genocide" in the city, and told the Kremlin leaders that they had to come to Bucha to see what their troops had done.
I want all the leaders of the Russian Federation to see how their orders are being carried out," Zelensky said in a video address, switching from Ukrainian to Russian.
It is a shared responsibility.
For these murders, for these tortures‚Ä¶ For the shots in the back of the head¬ª, he said.
He said that Russian President Vladimir Putin and the Russian military should be held accountable for the actions of the troops in Ukraine.

When we find people with their hands tied behind their backs and decapitated, I don't understand," he said of the scenes of victims scattered on the streets of Bucha, a city about 35 kilometers northwest of Kyiv.

In this case, according to the draft law, they can be released.
And then, most likely, this will lead to the loss of the quorum required by the supervisory board to make any decisions.

On the other hand, it will not be possible to quickly appoint new independent members of the supervisory board, as the law provides for the need to conduct a competitive selection, which takes an average of 3-4 months.
Therefore, the decision proposed by the bill 7176 is most likely not to prevent the supervisory board from making decisions, but rather the opposite will lead to this!
People's Deputy, author of the bill Dmytro Natalukha provides other arguments in support of it.

In particular, he notes: "many enterprises, in particular the defense-industrial complex (OIK), now need relocation" and therefore "it is difficult to imagine that a person can, for example, from Vienna via Zoom discuss addresses and other sensitive information.
To begin with, there are almost no state-owned defense enterprises in Ukraine, which have supervisory boards.
The Supervisory Board is only in "Ukroboronprom", which in fact implements the management of almost all state-owned enterprises of the defense industry complex.
But even in "Ukroboronprom", according to the law, the supervisory board has quite limited powers, and all its members perform their duties on a voluntary basis.

All the fullness of power in "Ukroboronrom" belongs to the general director, who, by the way, will also make decisions on the need to relocate this or that enterprise of the military-industrial complex, which is part of the concern.

In addition, such an argument does not withstand criticism because the draft law 7176 does not make any changes to the legislation regulating the activities of state-owned enterprises of the defense-industrial complex at all.
Dmytro Pan on his Facebook page also cites arguments that can be attributed to the "emotional" category.

Such arguments, as a rule, have nothing to do with increasing the efficiency of state companies and state banks, but let's try to analyze some of them: "respectable foreign experts, at the first word "war", left Ukraine in 2021, but at the same time remain members of the supervisory boards of state-owned enterprises of Ukraine with a full salary of several hundred thousand hryvnias, while Ukraine itself is really suffering from the war."<eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos>
First of all, this is a manipulation - most of these supervisory board members have never lived in Ukraine and only occasionally come here.
To say that they are "leaving Ukraine" is, to put it mildly, unfair.
Otherwise, as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, both foreign and Ukrainian members of supervisory boards have long been resorting to the practice of holding online meetings.
This tool is widely used in the world practice, and in absolutely different areas: business, education, medicine, etc.
It is also worth remembering that membership of the board of directors is not a full-time job.
As a rule, such people have another occupation, and it is just the means of electronic communication that help them in this.
Thirdly, all of these statements are read as claims exclusively to foreigners.
It is interesting why Mr. Dmytro does not express identical claims to the members of the supervisory boards who are Ukrainians?
Because they are also not at the location of their companies.
By the way, this is far from the first populist attempt by deputies to remove foreigners from supervisory boards, and the war is just a new convenient occasion.

The United States is banning investments in Russia and imposing sanctions on Putin's daughters

The United States, together with the G7 and the EU, are introducing new sanctions against the daughters of Russian President Putin, the largest Russian banks Alfa Bank and Sberbank, and are banning all new investments in Russia.
This is mentioned in a White House statement.
Sberbank is the largest financial institution in Russia, owned by the government, and Alfa-Bank is the largest private bank.
Sanctions will freeze any of their assets that relate to the U.S. financial system, and will prohibit U.S. citizens from doing business with them.
In addition, the States will introduce a complete ban on new investments in the Russian Federation.

With this in mind, U.S. President Joe Biden will sign a new executive order that includes a ban on new investments in Russia by U.S. citizens regardless of their location.<eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos><eos>

The private sector output includes producers, energy companies, large retailers, financial institutions, as well as other service providers, such as legal and consulting firms", the White House statement said.
The third step of the new sanctions from the United States were restrictions against large Russian state-owned enterprises in the critical sector.
It is prohibited for citizens of the United States to carry out operations with these organizations and freeze any of their assets in the jurisdiction of the United States.
The detailed list of the Ministry of Finance will be published on Thursday the next day.

The final part of the package is the full blocking of the assets of adult children of Putin, the wife and daughter of Foreign Minister Lavrov, as well as members of the Russian Security Council, including former President and Prime Minister of Russia Dmitry Medvedev and Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin.
